title: The line Sydney's wealthy downsizers won't cross
text:
Was it overpriced? The market determines. We had six contracts, so I’d have to say no. It’s worth what the market pays.

What did you think it would go for? We guided at $4 million and I thought it would go in the early 4s.

For them to say 'Potts Point' may be a bit too much, but they can say 'Paddington'. — Real estate agent Catherine Dixon

What was surprising about it?

We had six contracts out on it. All had up to $6 million to spend. I was surprised by the six contract holders and the 80-odd groups we had through – there were $5 million to $8 million properties on the market around Potts Point and Darling Point and no one was looking at those.

I’ve got something off-market in Darling Point I tried to offer and they all said “No way.” Potts Point is a bridge too far, even in the post-lockout era.

It’s especially [the case with] downsizers. These are people who have downsized from $9 million-$10 million properties. They’ve sold big houses in Bronte, Vaucluse, Tamarama. They were people who specifically wanted to live close to the city. Buyers are looking for a half-way point where they’ve got established shops. The [successful] buyers came from Vaucluse.

Advertisement

For them to say “Potts Point” may be a bit too much, but they can say “Paddington”. It’s gentrified and doesn’t have the craziness of Potts Point and is busier than Elizabeth Bay. But there is nothing we can offer there. There’s only one unit in every blue moon.

That area around Paddington and Woollahra village, if they can get a downsizing property that is not a house and is without stairs, that’s what they’re going for. I could sell 10 of those apartments.

It would be good to have $6 million and only have to spend $4 million because there’s really no choice.

Downsizing buyers from Sydney's outer eastern suburbs were keen to go close – but not too close – to the city.

There’s a hierarchy of streets in Paddington, but this isn’t one of them. This is at the end of Glenmore Road, where it meets Cascade Street. It is not one of the high-end streets such as Windsor Street or Paddington Street.

They were prepared to buy the property they wanted in the suburb they wanted but didn’t need to have it in one of the high-end streets.

If the lockout laws remain in place in King Cross – they’re starting to open up again in Darlinghurst – if they stay in place for the next five years, then the next stop for many of those moving to Paddington, the generation of late 40s, 50-year-olds, will go to Potts Point, but at the moment they won’t go there. Maybe in five years’ time they will go to Potts Point. But they just won’t go there at the moment.

Do you reckon we’ll see another result like this: a) next week b) next year c) next cycle d) never?

a) Next week. I’m going to sell one of the off-market apartments in the building to the left-over buyers. I’ve got enough buyers and we’re now getting to the end of the year and running out of time. These people are ready to buy. The owner is ready to sell. I’ll just slip them in.
description: If you've sold a house in Vaucluse, Paddington is an okay next step. But Potts Point? No way.
